title: Mill Gill and Whitfield Force Waterfalls Walking Route

images.title: Richard Spencer / Mill Gill Force, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Mill Gill Force. A wonderful walking area near Askrigg, can you spot the face in the rock?

images.title: Mick Garratt / Mill Gill, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Mill Gill. The gill is a minor tributary of the River Ure. William Wordsworth visited the valley in 1799 and wrote of it, and Turner came here and sketched the fall in 1816.

images.title: Karl and Ali / Whitfield Gill Force, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: People standing behind Whitfield Gill Force

images.title: Adie Jackson / Waterfall in woodland below Whitfield Gill Force, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Waterfall in woodland below Whitfield Gill Force

images.title: Whitfield Gill Lower Falls by Richard Spencer, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Whitfield Gill Lower Falls

images.title: Field gate, Low Straights Lane by Gordon Hatton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Field gate, Low Straights Lane. Just east of the falls.

images.title: Ray Woodcraft / Askrigg Mill
images.caption: Askrigg Mill. Just south of the falls. The mill was powered by the water of Mill Gill that runs through a pretty wooded glen. In 1908 the miller used the power of the water to provide electricity for the village.

images.title: Crown Inn, Askrigg by Philip Halling, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Crown Inn, Askrigg

description: Just above the little village of Askrigg in Wensleydale there is a lovely walking trail along a river with a series of pretty waterfalls and peaceful woodland. This walk starts in the village and follows the footpath to Mill Gill Force and Whitfield Force falls before returning through some beautiful Yorkshire Dales countryside. It's a really pleasant area with good signed paths, the sound of the running water and nice shady woodland. The long distance Herriot Way runs through the village. It takes you through areas of the Yorkshire Dales associated with the vet and author James Herriot. You can pick it up to extend your walking in this lovely area.
